summary: MERS-CoV was identified in patients with severe lower respiratory tract infections with almost 50% of cases resulting in lethal lower respiratory tract infections (1–5) there are no vaccines or effective therapies currently available for clinical cases of MERS-CoV infection. anti-CD26 polyclonal antibody (pAb) was used to inhibit in vitro MERS-CoV infection. pAbs to the MERS-CoV S1 domain effectively neutralize MERS-CoV infection (8). Fig. 2A, 2F9 inhibited full binding of MERS-CoV S1-Fc to JKT-hCD26WT. other anti-CD26 MAbs showed some inhibition (1F7 and YS110) or no significant inhibition (4G8, 16D4B, 9C11, and 14D10) the blocking effect of 2F9 was dose dependent. anti-CD26 MAb 2F9 has greater therapeutic potential than recombinant MERS-CoV S1-Fc to prevent viral entry into susceptible cells. anti-CD26 MAb 2F9 inhibits binding of MERS-CoV S1-Fc in parental Jurkat cells and CD26 Jurkat transfectants. mouse MAb 4G8, 1F7, 14D10, 2F9, 16D4B, or control IgG (black) for 30 min at 4°C. after being washed, cells were stained with Alexa Fluor 488-labeled MERS-CoV S1-Fc. results representative of three different experiments are shown as mean MFI. red bars at 0 g/ml of preincubated control IgG or anti-CD26 MAbs were plotted using the same data. the black and dark-gray bars at 0 g/ml of preincubated MERS-CoV S1-Fc or control Fc were plotted using the same data. the epitope of the anti-human CD26 MAb 2F9 was estimated to be located near the ADA binding region of CD26. the epitopes of the other anti-CD26 MAbs tested, including 1F7 and YS110, did not involve the ADA binding region (16). binding of exogenous ADA was detected on JKT-hCD26WT but not on CD26-negative parental Jurkat cells. MERS-CoV S1-Fc binding to JKT-hCD26-ADA was clearly observed at concentrations of 5 g/ml or greater. binding intensity appeared to be lower than that observed with JKT-hCD26WT (Fig. 1B), suggesting that the region where CD26 binds to MERS-CoV S1-Fc partially overlaps with its ADA binding regions. osine deaminase 1) in CD26 are involved in binding of MERS-CoV S1-Fc to human CD26. ADA was incubated with 10 g/ml of Alexa Fluor 488-labeled ADA or ADA2 as a fluorescence control. results representative of three different experiments shown as mean MFI. ADA2 or msIgG-488 as a fluorescence control. JKT-hCD26-ADA cells were stained with Alexa Fluor 488-labeled MERS-CoV S1-Fc (black) at the indicated concentrations. gray histograms show results for staining with Fc-488. the black and gray bars at 0 g/ml of preincubated ADA or vehicle were plotted using the same data. results representative of three different experiments are shown. binding efficiency was significantly decreased in comparison to that of the full-length human CD26 (Fig. 6a and black bars in graph) binding efficiency was significantly decreased in comparison with that of the full-length human CD26 (Fig. 6a and black bars in graph), which was at levels similar to those in mock-transfected cells. rat CD26 has been estimated not to bind to MERS-CoV. the full-length rat CD26 or rat-human swap mutant consisting of aa 1 to 739 of rat CD26 with aa 740 to 766 of human CD26 showed no binding to MERS-CoV S1-Fc, 2F9, or YS110. cDNAs with full-length human CD26 (a), the indicated deletion (b through f), human/rat swap mutants (h through j) or vector control (g) were cotransfected with GFP-expressing plasmids to COS-1 cells. TM indicates a transmembrane region of human CD26. amino acids (aa) derived from human (H) or rat (R) are represented in white or dark-gray boxes. 2F9 recognizes between 248 and 449 aa, including the ADA binding regions. 1F7 and YS110 recognize between 248 and 358 aa, excluding the ADA binding regions. humanized anti-CD26 MAb YS110 is being evaluated in patients with CD26-expressing cancers. no apparent adverse effects of YS110 have been reported besides the injection reaction. YS110 may be an immediate therapeutic candidate for clinical use. the humanized anti-CD26 MAb YS110 is ready for testing as a potential treatment for MERS-CoV infection in the present outbreaks.
